title: Brothers 'saved drug factory house fire then left their granny to burn to death'
text:
Gladys Ann Willow died in a house fire after grandsons Jarret Gause (top right) and his brother Justin saved their meth making equipment, then smoked a cigarette without trying to save her, police say (Pictures: WETM)

Two brothers rushed to save crystal meth-making equipment after their house caught fire – then left their granny to burn to death inside, police say.

Jarret and Justin Gause were charged with second-degree murder on Monday, five months after the death of 82 year-old Gladys Ann Willow at her home in Elmira, New York.

The siblings are reported to have saved the drug-manufacturing gear, then went outside to smoke a cigarette without reporting the blaze.

Willow died of injuries sustained while trapped inside the burning property, the Elmira Star-Gazette reported.

Her grandsons had originally been charged with manslaughter, but prosecutors upgraded the charges after alleging that the brothers’ reckless actions were worthy of a more serious charge.

WETM reported that the Gauses have also been charged with a count of reckless endangerment for every firefighter who battled the inferno.

They are further accused of tampering with evidence for allegedly moving the drug equipment.

Investigators later determined the house had been a makeshift meth factory.

Willow died from injuries she sustained after being trapped in the burning home. Her grandsons have now been charged with her second-degree murder, as well as endangering the safety of every firefighter who attended the blaze (Picture: WETM)

Jarrett Gause was re-arrested last week and is being held in Steuben County Jail.

Justin Gause is currently free on bond, with both siblings set to be arraigned at a later date.
description: Jarrett Gause and his brother Justin reportedly saved their meth lab in Elmira, New York, and went outside to smoke a cigarette
